dataset.title: Continuously measured soil moisture, soil temperature, and air temperature from stations in Watershed 32, Coweeta Hydrologic Laboratory

creator.organizationName: Coweeta Long Term Ecological Research Program

address.deliveryPoint: Daniel B. Warnell School of Forestry and Natural Resources

abstract.para: Long-term soil moisture stations were established within the Coweeta Hydrologic Lab Basin to collect measurements of soil moisture, soil temperature, air temperature, and relative humidity at a range of spatial scales, from ridge to cove and low to high elevations in the southern Appalachians, and across the regional range of rainfall amounts.

section.title: Air Temperature/Relative Humidity
section.para: Air temperature (& relative humidity if equipped) sensors are installed within gill-plated radiation shields attached to the datalogger enclosure post, between 1-1.7 meters above ground surface.

methodStep.instrumentation: Air temperture probe: Campbell Scientific model 107. Relative Humidity sensor: Campbell Scientific HC2S3 probe

section.title: Soil Moisture
section.para: Soil Moisture: Probes are located at depths of 0-30cm and 30-60cm below the mineral soil surface. For ridge stations, probes are installed along the ridge, appx. 6 meters away from plot center, in opposite directions. For side-slope stations, probes are installed appx. 6 meters upslope and 6 meters downslope of plot center. For cove stations, probes are installed as close as possible to the long axis of the direction of the cove, both on a line intersecting the plot center and at least 5 meters between probe locations. Regardless of station type, all soil moisture sensors are within the 15 meter radius plot. Probes at different depths are located within 1 meter of each other and probes at any one depth should be at least 5 meters apart within the plot.

methodStep.instrumentation: Soil moisture probes: Campbell Scientific model CS650

section.title: Soil Temperature
section.para: Soil Temperature: Each soil moisture probe also measures soil temperature from the epoxy head of the sensor. This allows for soil temperature measurements taken at the mineral soil surface, and at 30cm below mineral soil surface. Additionally,temperature probes are installed horizontally at 5cm and 20cm below mineral soil surface.

methodStep.instrumentation: Soil temperature probes: Campbell Scientific model CS650, Campbell Scientific model 107

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: CWT Study Site WS32 -- Watershed 32, Macon County, North Carolina, USA. Control with mixed hardwoods stands remaining undisturbed since 1927.
CWT Study Site CWTBASIN -- Coweeta Basin, Macon County, North Carolina, USA. The overall boundary for the Coweeta Hydrologic laboratory.

section.title: Watershed 32 Microclimate Measurements
section.para: The site coordinates listed are for the plot center. The datalogger enclosure is located within 7.5 meters of plot center. The main plot has a 15 meter radius and contains subplots for soil and vegetation measurements. 132: 35.051459 N, 83.462251 W, elevation: 1121.8 meters 232: 35.0506480 N, 83.46062913 W, elevation: 1044.6 meters 332: 35.0493880 N, 83.45858537 W, elevation: 971.3 meters

Long-term soil moisture stations were established within the Coweeta Hydrologic Lab Basin to collect measurements of soil moisture, soil temperature, air temperature, and relative humidity at a range of spatial scales, from ridge to cove and low to high elevations in the southern Appalachians, and across the regional range of rainfall amounts.

Measurements are taken and output to the data table at 5 minute intervals using Campbell Scientific Instruments sensors and a CR1000 datalogger. Data is collected remotely through radio telemetry or modem. The data is processed at the Coweeta LTER Information Management Office daily and posted online in the streaming data portal of the Coweeta LTER website.

abstract.para: The Coweeta LTER Research Program has evolved since 1980 from a site-based to a site- and region-based project examining the effects of disturbance and environmental gradients on biogeochemical cycling, and the underlying watershed ecosystem processes that regulate and respond to those cycles. The current interdisciplinary research integrates ecological and socioeconomic components across 54,000 km2 of the southern Appalachian Mountains, a biogeophysical and socioeconomic region in which evolutionary and historical processes converge (Whittaker 1956, Markusen 1987, Barnes 1991, Kretzschmar et al. 1993, Bailey 1996). Our research objective in 2002-2008 is to advance scientific understanding of the spatial, temporal, and decision-making components of land use and land-use change in the southern Appalachian Mountains over the last 200 years, and forecast patterns into the future 30 years. Our guiding hypothesis is that the frequency, intensity, and extent of land use represents human decision-making in response to socioeconomic and biogeophysical conditions with consequences that cascade through ecosystems.

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant number OCE-9982133. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.
